column1: BUFR Table B — Classification of elements

column2: Where a code table or flag table is appropriate, “code table” or “flag table” respectively is entered in the UNITS column.
The code tables and flag tables associated with Table B are numbered to correspond with the F, X and Y part of the table reference.

To encode values into BUFR, the data (with units as specified in the UNITS column) must be multiplied by 10 to the power SCALE.  Then subtract the REFERENCE VALUE to give the coded value found in Section 4 of the BUFR message.  For example, a measured latitude is –45.76 degrees.  The coarse accuracy descriptor is 0 05 002 and the encoded value is –45.76 x 102 – (–9000) = 4424.

Where UNITS are given as CCITT IA5, data shall be coded as character data left justified within the field width indicated using CCITT International Alphabet No. 5, and blank filled to the full field width indicated.
Classes 48 to 63 are reserved for local use; all other classes are reserved for future development.
Entries 192 to 255 within all classes are reserved for local use.

The use of local descriptors, as defined in Notes (5) and (6), in messages intended for non-local or international exchange is strongly discouraged.  They should be kept to the barest minimum possible and must also be by-passed by the use of descriptor 2 06 YYY.
First-order statistics are included in Table B only when they are produced, as such, by the observing system.

column2: The storm identifier (descriptor 0 01 025) has the following meaning:  the first two characters shall be a numeric sequence number assigned by the originator of the message; the third character is a letter indicating the ocean basin where the storm is located, as follows:
N Atlantic Ocean, including Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico
RSMC Nadi's zone in South Pacific

column1: There is no requirement that differing observers coordinate sequence numbers even though they both may be reporting the same storm.

column2: WMO storm name (descriptor 0 01 027): the storm name NAMELESS shall be used in those cases where an identifiable tropical disturbance has not reached tropical storm strength and has not been assigned an official name.
Where a centre other than the originating centre generates quality information, replacement or substitute values, and/or statistical information, the centre may be indicated by using 0 01 033.

A generating centre may wish to indicate a reference to the application that generated quality information, etc.; it may use descriptor 0 01 032 for this purpose.  However, the corresponding code tables will vary from centre to centre.
Code table 0 01 032 is to be generated by each centre.
The components of absolute platform velocity (0 01 041, 0 01 042, 0 01 043) are defined as follows:
First component: From the Earth’s centre to 0 degree longitude at the Equator: velocity of the platform along this line relative to the Earth’s centre.
Second component:  From the Earth’s centre to 90 degrees East longitude at the Equator: velocity of the platform along this line relative to the Earth’s centre.
Third component:  From the Earth’s centre to the North Pole: velocity of the platform along this line relative to the Earth’s centre.

The values for descriptors 0 01 041, 0 01 042 and 0 01 043 have been chosen to be suitable for polar orbiting satellites in approximately Sun-synchronous orbits.  Geostationary orbits would require greater data widths for distance and slightly less for speed.
Left handed xyz axes have been chosen for descriptors 0 01 041, 0 01 042 and 0 01 043.
Descriptor 0 01 020 should be used instead of 0 01 004 for encoding this element.

Descriptor 0 01 033 shall be used instead of descriptor 0 01 031 for encoding originating/generating centre.  Code table 0 01 034 is to be established by the associated originating/generating centre identified by descriptor 0 01 033 and provided to the Secretariat for publication.

For 0 01 022, the character string representing the “Name of feature” should be of the form: “Type of phenomenon” – “Location or geographical name” (e.g.: “volcano – Popocatepetl”, “oil fire – Kuwait”)

column2: This class shall contain elements to describe the instrumentation used to obtain the meteorological elements reported.
This class may also contain elements relating to observational procedures.
Some indication of expected accuracy may be implied in conjunction with certain elements in this class.
Note that descriptor 0 02 140 is the Azimuth angle measured anticlockwise from satellite heading vector.
In descriptor 0 02 142:  Ozone instrument serial number/identification is four characters long. For Japanese Dobsons instruments, omit the leading digit(s).
Descriptor 0 02 019 should be used instead of descriptor 0 02 152 for single satellite instrument identification.

column4: Reference time period for accumulated or extreme data
Duration of time relating to following value
Duration of time relating to following value
Number of days with precipitation equal to or more than 1 mm

column2: The significance of time periods or displacements shall be indicated using the time significance code corresponding to table reference 0 08 021.

Where more than one time period or displacement is required to define complex time structures, they shall be defined in immediate succession, and the following ordering shall apply:  ensemble period (if required), followed by forecast period (if required), followed by period for averaging or accumulation (if required).
Time periods or displacements and time increments require an initial time location to be defined prior to their use, followed where appropriate by a time significance definition.

The time location, when used with forecast values, shall indicate the time of the initial state for the forecast, or the beginning of the forecast period; when used with ensemble means of forecast values, the time location shall indicate the initial state or the beginning of the first forecast over which ensemble means are derived.
Negative time periods or displacements shall be used to indicate time periods or displacements preceding the currently defined time.
Descriptor 0 04 041 has been replaced by the combination of 0 08 025 and 0 26 003 and should not be used for encoding this element.
All times are Universal Time Coordinated (UTC) unless otherwise noted.

column4: Ship transect number according to SOOP

column2: Values of latitude and latitude increments are limited to the range –90 degrees to +90 degrees.
South latitude shall be assigned negative values.
North to south increments shall be assigned negative values.
Bearing or azimuth shall only be used with respect to a stated location, and shall not redefine that location.
The Pixel size on horizontal – 1 is given at location where map scale factor is unity.
Values of longitude are limited to the range –180 degrees to +180 degrees.
West longitude shall be assigned negative values.
East to west increments shall be assigned negative values.
Distance shall only be used with respect to a stated location and a bearing, azimuth or elevation; it shall not redefine that location.
The Pixel size on horizontal – 2 is given at location where map scale factor is unity.

column4: Height above station (sensor height artificially corrected) (see Note 2)

column2: Elevation shall only be used with respect to a stated location and a bearing, azimuth or distance; it shall not redefine that location.

Height above station at which sensor height is artificially corrected to standard value using formula.  For example, standard height for wind is 10 metres but anemometers or buoys are placed at much lower height; such height is sometimes corrected using a formula.

column2: Where values are accumulated or averaged (for example over a time period), the total number of values from which the accumulated or averaged values are obtained may be represented using reference 0 08 022.
A previously defined significance may be cancelled by transmitting a “missing” from the appropriate code or flag table.
First order statistics have values with a similar range and the same dimensions as the corresponding reported values (e.g., maxima, minima, means, etc.).

Difference statistics are difference values; they have dimensions similar to the corresponding reported values with respect to units, but assume a range centred on zero (e.g., the difference between reported and analysed values, the difference between reported and forecast values, etc.).
Descriptor 0 08 025 is to be used with 0 26 003 (time difference).
Descriptor 0 08 033 is to be used by preceding the element 0 33 007 as part of quality control information in order to specify the method used to calculate the percentage confidence.

Left handed xyz axes have been chosen for descriptor 0 10 031.

column2: West to east u-components shall be assigned positive values.
South to north v-components shall be assigned positive values.
Upward w-components shall be assigned positive values where units are m s–1.

The steadiness factor (descriptor 0 11 019) is the ratio of speed of the monthly mean vector wind to the speed of the monthly mean scalar wind expressed as a percentage.  It is reported to the nearest one percent.

column2: Where the expression “at height and over period specified” is entered under ELEMENT NAME, an appropriate vertical location shall be specified using descriptors from class 07, together with an appropriate period using descriptors from class 04.
Descriptor 0 12 076 should be used instead of descriptor 0 12 072 to encode radiance.
A precipitation value of -0.1kg m-2 before scaling (-1 after scaling or in CREX) shall indicate a "trace" (non-measurable, less than 0.05 kg m-2).

A snow depth value of -0.01 m before scaling (-1 after scaling or in CREX) shall indicate a little (less than 0.005 m) snow.  A value of -0.02 m (-2 after scaling or in CREX) shall indicate "snow cover not continuous".

The “parcel lifted index” (as defined in the International Meteorological Vocabulary (WMO–No. 182) under the listing “lifted index”) is defined as the temperature difference between the ambient 500 hPa temperature (T500) and that of a parcel of air lifted from the surface (Tparcel) following the dry and moist adiabatic process.  Negative values of (T500 – Tparcel) suggest instability.  The “best lifted index” is defined as the most unstable of a collection of parcel lifted indices, with parcel initial conditions defined for a collection of 30 hPa thick layers stacked one upon the other with the lowest resting on the ground.  Commonly four to six such layers are used in the calculation.
Since the two lifted indices (042 and 043) are defined as temperature differences, they may take on negative values, even though the units are kelvin; hence the non-zero reference value.
Descriptor 0 13 033 should be used instead of descriptor 0 13 032 to encode evaporation/evapotranspiration.

column2: 0 15 003 is partial pressur of ozone, measured at the pressure level identified by 0 07 004.

column1: where TOI is the integrated ozone value obtained "simultaneously to a sounding" from a Dobson or Brewer spectrophotometer at the site or "nearby" and TOS is the total ozone obtained from the sounding.  TOS is sum of the integrated ozone below the lowest pressure level reached by the sounding and the estimate of the amount above.  In the absence of any spectrophotometer measurement, CF = Missing value.

column2: 0 15 005 is the value obtained as the result of the vertical integration of the sounding values (0 15 003) measured below the lowest pressure level reached by the sonde, multiplied by 0 15 004.

column2: When encoding present weather reported from an automatic weather station, the appropriate combination of descriptors 0-20-021, 0-20-022, 0-20-023, 0-20-024, 0-20-025, 0-20-026 and 0-20-027 should be used and preferred.  A descriptor 0-20-003 should be used only when descriptors mentioned above are not applicable.

When encoding past weather reported from an automatic weather station, the appropriate combination of descriptors 0-20-021, 0-20-022, 0-20-023, 0-20-024, 0-20-025, 0-20-026 and 0-20-027 should be used and preferred.  Descriptors 0-20-004 or 0-20-005 should be used only when descriptors mentioned above are not applicable.

The data width for descriptor 0 20 038 originally defined to be 12 is wrong.  Nine bits are sufficient as for all the other “degree true” quantities.  However, the 12-bit width is maintained for historical consistency.

column2: The significant wave height is defined as four times the square root of the energy spectrum integrated over direction and frequency.  It corresponds to about the height that one-third of all waves exceed.
The dominant wave is the one that has the maximum energy in the energy spectrum.
Mean Wave Direction is the angle alpha 1 and Principal Wave Direction is the angle alpha 2, in the expression S(f, alpha) approximately equals:

column1: c11 x (0.5 + r1 x cos (alpha-alpha 1) + r2 x cos (2 (alpha-alpha 2) ) ) / pi

in which S(f, alpha) is the wave directional spectrum and c11 is the non directional spectrum, and the right hand side of this expression is the first two terms of the Fourier series expansion of S(f, alpha).  If the mean and principal directions differ significantly (e.g, more than 15 degrees) for a given frequency, crossing seas are indicated.

column2: Descriptor 0 22 040 should be used instead of 0 22 039 for encoding meteorological residual tidal elevation (surge or offset).

column1: 0 22 101 nominal input range 0 – 2 x 106, but may be greater because of uncertainty.

column2: Descriptors 0 22 001, 0 22 002, 0 22 003: the direction given in these entries is the direction which waves are coming from.

column2: The alternate latitude may be used when the computation of the position yields multiple solutions and there is no a priori way to distinguish between them.
The satellite location counter is calculated as:
counter = superswath no. x 1000 + box no. x 10 + minibox no.
The satellite sublocation dimension is calculated as:

The value for descriptor 0 27 031 has been chosen to be suitable for polar orbiting satellites in approximately sun-synchronous orbits.  Geostationary orbits would require greater data widths for distance and slightly less for speed.
Left handed xyz axes have been chosen for descriptor 0 27 031.

column2: The alternate longitude may be used when the computation of the position yields multiple solutions and there is no a priori way to distinguish between them.

The value for descriptor 0 28 031 has been chosen to be suitable for polar orbiting satellites in approximately sun-synchronous orbits.  Geostationary orbits would require greater data widths for distance and slightly less for speed.
Left handed xyz axes have been chosen for descriptor 0 28 031.
Pixel data width can be changed with descriptor 2 01 YYY.

In order to distinguish unambiguously the cases of missing data and saturated pixels, n-bit image data should be encoded using a data width of n+1.  Where such a descriptor is not already available in Class 30, operator descriptor 2 01 YYY should be used to modify the data width of the existing entry as required.

column1: Class 31 - Data description operator qualifiers (this class does not exist in CREX)

column4: Delayed descriptor and data repetition factor
Extended delayed descriptor and data repetition factor

column1: (1) The “delayed descriptor and data repetition factor” is intended for run-length encoding (e.g. scanning an image).  It specifies a count N which applies to both descriptor and data, i.e. the value of the single element defined by the following descriptor is repeated N times (at intervals already specified).

(2) Descriptor 0 31 031, used in conjunction with quality control or statistics operators 2 22 YYY through 2 32 YYY, shall indicate the presence of quality control information when the indicator value is set to zero.  It may be used, in conjunction with the replication operator 1 01 YYY, to construct a table of data present/not present indicators, forming a data present bit-map as defined in Regulation 94.5.5.3.  This makes it possible to present quality control information and statistical information for selected data corresponding to element descriptors which precede the 2 22 to 32 YYY operators.

column2: Other applications of the data present indicator may be developed.
